Event.EventDescription: This introductory course, kicking off Science Week, will cover principles and “rules of the science-writing game”, thus equipping researchers and managers with the confidence and media savvy required to project messages clearly. Please call for more information and to reserve a place.

Hands-on training will be provided in preparing articles, features, media releases and illustrative material for multiple outlets, including in-house, local and international publications and the digital media. In addition, the sessions will groom participants for science interviews by the media.
Event.EventPayment: $180, includes materials and light refreshments. (Concessions available on request.)

Event.EventDescription: This special one day pre National Science Week course will teach the essential skills and strategies needed to convey the fruits of scientific research to the media, government, research-funding bodies and the public.
Event.EventPayment: $80, includes reference materials and a one-month follow-up period for advice and assistance on any aspect of the course.

Event.EventDescription: In this art exhibition (14-31 August) titled 'Umwelten - eco-fields and other universes' Spear's circular paintings on wood suggest an interplay between the world of the senses, remote sensing and unseen networks of connections beyond the human sensorium, mapping an ecosystem of other universes.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Level 8, Room 16 Nicholas Building 37 Swanston Street

Event.EventDescription: The Clare Valley Science Spectacular is a week-long festival science. Events include the Starlab planetarium, science fair, science shows and screening of the inspiring documentary "Inventing Tomorrow". Big problems can be solved with STEM-based thinking. Be involved, engaged & part of the solution.

Deakin University and Victorian Fisheries Authority are hosting an Open Day at the Queenscliff Marine Station. Come along to learn about marine science and the weird and wonderful marine creatures that call Port Phillip Bay home.

Speak face-to-face with some of Tasmania's brightest science minds about climate change issues most important to residents in South and Central Tasmania. We'll reveal answers to some of the most popular questions submitted through an ABC Radio call-out, plus live Q & A with UTAS & CSIRO scientists.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies

Venue.VenueName: Sir Stanley Burbury Theatre - University of Tasmania (Sandy Bay Campus)

Event.EventName: Curious Climate Tasmania - East Coast TAS
Event.EventDescription: Speak face-to-face with some of Tasmania's brightest science minds about climate change issues most important to residents on the East Coast. We'll reveal answers to some of the most popular questions submitted through an ABC Radio call-out, plus live Q & A with UTAS & CSIRO scientists.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies

Event.EventDescription: Speak face-to-face with some of Tasmania's brightest science minds about climate change issues most important to residents in North & Central Tasmania. We'll reveal answers to some of the most popular questions submitted through an ABC Radio call-out, plus live Q & A with UTAS & CSIRO scientists.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies

Venue.VenueName: Rory Spence Lecture Theatre - University of Tasmania (Inveresk Campus)

Event.EventName: Curious Climate Tasmania - West Coast TAS
Event.EventDescription: Speak face-to-face with some of Tasmania's brightest science minds about climate change issues that are most important to residents on the West Coast. We'll reveal answers to some of the most popular questions submitted through an ABC Radio call-out, plus live Q & A with UTAS & CSIRO scientists.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Institute of Marine and Antarctic Studies

Event.EventDescription: St Brigid’s Catholic School will be hosting a science fair as part of National Science Week.

The Girl’s Day Out in STEM event is aimed at young regional girls in the greater Port Macquarie area who are currently in Years 5 to 8. The event is a fun carnival-like atmosphere celebrating and sharing the power of knowledge.
Event.EventPayment: $75 entry fee. Free for sponsored school representatives

Event.EventName: VCE Chemistry Workshop - The Chemistry of Medicines, Functional groups and Chirality
Event.EventDescription: A fantastic opportunity for VCE Chemistry students to apply their understanding of functional groups, chirality and problem solving to the context of pharmacy and pharmacology. Come along and extend yourself in preparation for your exams and future in the health care and research sectors.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Monash University, Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

Venue.VenueName: Monash University Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

Event.EventDescription: Take a look into the sparkling world of water and see if you can spot the tiny creatures who call the river home. Catch some, test out your identification skills and explore what these little creatures might grow up to be.
Event.EventPayment: $6 per child

Event.EventDescription: This annual event is a multi faceted day of learning for both science teachers and Year 10 students. They get the opportunity to delve deeper into the science, ethics, career pathways and the real human stories of those living with Huntington’s disease in this popular and immersive event.

Venue.VenueName: Harry Perkins Institute of Medical Research

Event.EventDescription: Come and explore 4 fun science experiments including water fireworks, magic milk, bouncy balls and lava lamps. For children aged 5+.

Event.EventName: How Different Species Grow Within Our World
Event.EventDescription: Through exploration of X-rays, skeletal structures and internal processes we will explore and investigate how different species grow, eat, process food and survive. We will investigate how our environment has an impact upon how we live and stay healthy.
Do science, meet scientists and explore new technologies with a spectacular week-long celebration of science at Gold Coast Libraries.

Celebrate National Science Week with a BANG! Join the Scientwists for this fun and creative show demonstrating all things TwistED science. There’ll be plenty of hands-on opportunities for willing participants and heaps to see and wonder about.

Event.EventName: Luminary Lecture: Australia in space and Apollo - presented by Professor Alan Duffy
Event.EventDescription: Join science star Professor Alan Duffy as he explores Australia in space, and the unthinkable technologies allowing the next Space Race to be between startups not superpowers, and the ways in which Australia finds itself at the cutting-edge of space exploration.

Event.EventName: Graeme Clark Oration - Towards an electronic prescription?
Event.EventDescription: The 2019 Graeme Clark Orator, Professor Timothy Denison, will highlight the challenges and opportunities in using bioelectronics to treat a range of neurological conditions.

Monash University's Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences is number three in the world for Pharmacy and Pharmacology. On Open day we open our doors to the public to find out why we are so good at what we do. Join us for a day of scientific exploration!
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Monash University, Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

Venue.VenueName: Monash University Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

Event.EventName: International Year of the Periodic Table Expo
Event.EventDescription: Join us as we celebrate the International Year of the Periodic Table 2019 with the IYPT Expo and be inspired by the science of chemistry.
Scientists go head-to-head in the ultimate science quiz show event. Featuring exciting science, laughs and audience participation.
The Festival of Soil - a celebration of the hidden worlds beneath our feet, explored through art, science and storytelling.

Event.EventName: How Neutrons Can Save the World
Event.EventDescription: They're small, neutral and often in a spin - so much more than ‘just’ part of the atom. Neutrons are the sub-atomic particles that are here to save the world! Speaker Dr Helen Maynard-Casely from ANSTO will tell you how neutrons are here to shed light and solve the grand challenges we face today.

Venue.VenueName: Physics Lecture Theatre 1, Sandy Bay Campus, University of Tasmania

Event.EventDescription: Cruise, Immerse, Learn & Act with CoralWatch in Moreton Bay.
Event.EventPayment: $7.50 per person

Event.EventDescription: Can you kick the physics out of a footy? Can you make a boomerang come back? How fast can you run in a sprint test? And how much energy can you generate on a skate ramp?

An after-school science show for junior/primary school aged children at the Two Wells Council Chambers next door to the library. Demonstrating concepts of energy, pressure, critical thinking and combustion, there will be lots of loud noises, liquid nitrogen, explosions, and a ride-on hovercraft.

Venue.VenueName: Two Wells Old Council Chamber Building

Event.EventName: Into the Vaults - an evening at the state's zoology collection
Event.EventDescription: Unlock the vault and explore a space rarely seen by the public. You'll have an opportunity to be guided by TMAG scientists while investigating a collection that covers whales to weevils and thousands of animals in between. You'll also hear all about TMAG's latest research on Tasmanian animals.

Event.EventName: Into the Vaults - an evening at the state's zoology collection
Event.EventDescription: Unlock the vault and explore a space rarely seen by the public. You'll have an opportunity to be guided by TMAG scientists while investigating a collection that covers whales to weevils and thousands of animals in between. You'll also hear all about TMAG's latest research on Tasmanian animals.

Event.EventName: Winning Sky Photos: astronomy talk and tour
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Sarah Reeves, astronomer and curator at the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences for a tour of the astro-photographs of Winning Sky. She will also speak of the new Apollo 11 Exhibition at the Power House.

Dr Sarah Reeves, astronomer and curator at the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences will speak of the new Apollo 11 Exhibition at the Power House. She will also explain the night sky referencing the Winning Sky photos on exhibition in the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum.

Dr Sarah Reeves, astronomer and curator at the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences will speak of the new Apollo 11 Exhibition at the Power House. She will also explain the night sky referencing the Winning Sky photos on exhibition in the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum.

Event.EventName: The Cat in the Box: Schrodinger's Paradox
Event.EventDescription: Award-winning physicist, quantum scientist and author, Dr Chris Ferrie, has transformed Schrodinger's Paradox into a whimsical tale perfect for science fans. Chris will talk of quantum physics and technology, show how to explain complex scientific topics and to grow and encourage young scientists.
Dr Chris Ferrie, award-winning physicist, quantum scientist and author will workshop writing about science and will guide participants in the creation of their own science book.

Event.EventName: Marine Plastics: Finding solutions by linking science and community
Event.EventDescription: Have you event wondered how marine plastics are transported around the world? What their impact on marine life is? And how the community can help reduce the amount of plastics entering the marine environment? We tackle these issues through three short talks and Q and A forum with local experts.

Event.EventName: Science in the House: Open House at the Architecture Museum
Event.EventDescription: Historically, science has played an important part in the design of homes. Come in for a behind the scenes lunchtime open house in the University of South Australia’s Architecture Museum examining architectural drawings and archives to uncover some of the mysteries of our homes.

Venue.VenueName: Architecture Museum, University of South Australia

Event.EventName: Habitat Corridors: The Fabric of Local Ecosystems Workshop #1
Event.EventDescription: An immersive science and creative interactive workshop process. The program will consist of a presentation of scientific information regarding threatened species and the habitats vital for their sustainability in our region, as well as a related creative workshop program and a public forum.

Event.EventName: Habitat Corridors: The Fabric of Local Ecosystems Workshop #2
Event.EventDescription: An immersive science and creative interactive workshop process. The program will consist of a presentation of scientific information regarding threatened species and the habitats vital for their sustainability in our region, as well as a related creative workshop program and a public forum.

Event.EventName: Habitat Corridors: The Fabric of Local Ecosystems Public Forum & Exhibition Opening
Event.EventDescription: An immersive science and creative interactive workshop process. The program will consist of a presentation of scientific information regarding threatened species and the habitats vital for their sustainability in our region, as well as a related creative workshop program and a public forum.

Event.EventName: CoralWatch at the Brisbane Science Festival
Event.EventDescription: Coral Reefs Immerse, Learn & Act. Interactively learn about the importance of coral reefs and their threats using Virtual Reality technology and a large virtual reef at the stall.
Event.EventPayment: Free for children under 15; Adults $18.41; Concession $12.64

Event.EventDescription: The Perth Science Festival is back for another year! Experience more than 50 hands-on activities, explosive shows, roving performers, native animals, competitions and more.
Event.EventPayment: All tickets $10. Children under 4 free. Companions accompanying another with a valid companion card are free.

Event.EventName: Makings of a Malignancy: The world's first cancer-themed escape room
Event.EventDescription: Have you wondered what cancer is, how does it occur, and why some cancers are curable while others are not? Be transported to an immersive experience to see first-hand the journey of a cancer cell throughout the body.
Event.EventPayment: We will have free entry and ticketed events throughout August. Follow our Facebook page for more information.

Event.EventName: Publish or Perish: the future of academic publishing and biomedical research
Event.EventDescription: The digital revolution is disrupting academic and scholarly publishing. The Open Access publishing model is gaining support in academia. This event will explore the reasons for this shift and if it will result in improved public access while maintaining research quality.

Event.EventName: Autism-friendly Family Morning: National Photographer of the Year
Event.EventDescription: Designed specifically for children with autism and their families, we’ll host a unique morning experience. Before we open to the public, you’ll have a chance to explore all the galleries and the Discovery Centre. Information on booking will be available from 25 July.

Come behind the scenes at the South Australian Museum. Meet our scientists, explore the Science Centre and get a rare look at our collections! See the Museum’s collections and research facilities up close, and talk to the scientists who use and care for the collections.

Event.EventName: Sprigg lecture series: Associate Professor Amy Roberts - Aboriginal Transitions in the Murray River Corridor - From the Pleistocene to the Present
Event.EventDescription: Associate Professor Amy Roberts is an archaeologist and anthropologist who works collaboratively with Aboriginal communities in South Australia. Her talk will focus on a broad ranging project with the River Murray and Mallee Aboriginal Corporation.

Event.EventName: Kitchen Science and Amazing Chocolate Creations
Event.EventDescription: Be prepared for an exciting journey of discovery in the chocolate kitchen where tasty morsels will be created and the chemical reactions explained.
Event.EventPayment: $2 per person

Event.EventName: Kitchen Science and Amazing Chocolate Creations
Event.EventDescription: Be prepared for an exciting journey of discovery in the chocolate kitchen where tasty morsels will be created and the chemical reactions explained.
Event.EventPayment: $2 per person

Event.EventDescription: The Nature of Science Community Expo is an exciting, interactive one-day event that investigates how we strive to make sense of our natural world and adapt to changes in meaningful ways through activities and displays.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Cnr Queens Park Road & Kent Street

Event.EventName: Mission Imagination: to the Moon and beyond
Event.EventDescription: A community engaged exhibition that takes people through the timeline of space exploration starting with the ancient astronomy of our Noongar peoples and weaving through the Moon landing and launching into the future of space science.

As part of the Beaker St @TMAG weekend in Hobart, a fully catered guided walk will be offered which retraces most of Sir Charles Darwin's climb of kunanyi / Mt Wellington. The walk will celebrate the rich natural sciences of the mountain, visiting the sites of numerous ground breaking discoveries.
Event.EventPayment: $150 adults, $140 concession, $100 children under 13. Includes transport and catering.

Event.EventDescription: Woodland birds are being caught, banded and released to document their survival and movements in the Monarto area. BioR is helping university scientists with this, providing opportunities for the public and school groups to see how the birds are caught, to hold them and release them.

To mark the 50th anniversary of the first Moon landing, scientist Peter Eyland from the Sutherland Astronomical Society shares the remarkable history of space flight and details NASA’s plans to eventually land a human on Mars.

Event.EventName: Into the Vaults of the Tasmanian Herbarium
Event.EventDescription: Come to the Tasmanian Herbarium and see the world’s largest collection of Tasmanian plant specimens. Join its curators to hear of famous sea voyages, moss from the bones of a dead bushranger, and plants as rare as orange-bellied parrots.

Event.EventName: Dark, Creepy, Cool. Movie screening of Sixteen Legs
Event.EventDescription: Screening of SIXTEEN LEGS a nature documentary like no other, set in a magical underground ecosystem hidden beneath one of the world's last great wildernesses. Screening daily throughout National Science Week at the Marakoopa Cafe. Venue is close to Mole Creek Caves Ticket Office
Event.EventPayment: $15 Adult; $10 under 12s
Event.EventMoreInfo: Venue is close to Mole Creek Caves Ticket Office

Event.EventName: Dark, Creepy, Cool. Movie screening of Sixteen Legs
Event.EventDescription: Screening of SIXTEEN LEGS a nature documentary like no other, set in a magical underground ecosystem hidden beneath one of the world's last great wildernesses. Screening daily throughout National Science Week at the Marakoopa Cafe. Venue is close to Mole Creek Caves Ticket Office
Event.EventPayment: $15 Adult; $10 under 12s

Event.EventPayment: $15 Adult; $10 under 12s
