Event.EventName: Dark, Creepy, Cool. Movie screening of Sixteen Legs
Event.EventDescription: Screening of SIXTEEN LEGS a nature documentary like no other, set in a magical underground ecosystem hidden beneath one of the world's last great wildernesses. Screening daily throughout National Science Week at the Marakoopa Cafe. Venue is close to Mole Creek Caves Ticket Office
Event.EventPayment: $15 Adult; $10 under 12s
Event.EventMoreInfo: Venue is close to Mole Creek Caves Ticket Office

Event.EventName: Painting a changing world: how art and science can speak together in a time of environmental change. A special Hadley’s Art Prize event
Event.EventDescription: Why do palaeoecologists look at art? What is the role of art in conservation? And how might art and science come together to help us respond to environmental change? Come and hear scientists, artists and curators reflect at a special Hadley's Art Prize afternoon tea (tea, coffee & scones provided).
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Menzies Institute for Medical Research, University of Tasmania

Event.EventName: Operation Earth: A Conservation Mission - Family Day
Event.EventDescription: Taronga Zoo Sydney and the University of Sydney invite you to OPERATION EARTH: A Conservation Mission on Saturday 17 August 2019. Threatened species need your help! Take on the University of Sydney’s science challenges to learn about the strategies in place to ensure a future for Earth’s wildlife.
Event.EventPayment: Children aged 4-15 years go FREE per 1 paying adult. Adult Zoo entry is $47 when purchased online. All children under 4 years of age are FREE. Additional children are $27 when purchased online.

Event.EventDescription: In a fishbowl-style public forum, research scientists and coffee professional will roleplay how they would roast, grind and extract quality coffee in the extremes of space.

Venue.VenueStreetName: The Pavilion Room (Level 8) 100 St Kilda Road

Event.EventDescription: Mount Stromlo Observatory in conjunction with the Canberra Astronomical Society invite the Canberra community to attend our public observing night during National Science Week. Come and see the rings of Saturn, the craters of the moon, and beautiful star clusters and nebulae.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Mount Stromlo Observatory via Cotter Road

Event.EventDescription: We will be challenging our pre-school participants to build with Duplo.
Take a walking tour of Mount Stromlo Observatory and explore its past, present, and future.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Mount Stromlo Observatory via Cotter Road

Event.EventDescription: The Innovators’ Tea Party are hosting eight free speed-networking events for students in Years 10, 11 and 12 to meet with a range of women working in a variety of science, technology, engineering, medicine and maths careers. Events are on Sunday 11 and Saturday 17 August at 9am, 11am, 1pm and 3pm.

Particle/Wave is an immersive multimedia exploration of gravitational waves where poetry, video art, music and science intersect. Following sell-out seasons at the Melbourne Festival 2018 and World Science Festival Brisbane come and see Particle/Wave under the planetarium dome. Shows at 7pm and 9pm
Event.EventPayment: $35 Adult, $32 concession and $30 Museums Victoria members

Event.EventDescription: Particle/Wave is an immersive multimedia exploration of gravitational waves where poetry, video art, music and science intersect. Following sell-out seasons at the Melbourne Festival 2018 and World Science Festival Brisbane come and see Particle/Wave under the planetarium dome. Shows at 11am, 1pm, 3pm, 6pm and 8pm daily

Venue.VenueName: Adelaide Planetarium, UniSA, Mawson Lakes Campus

Event.EventDescription: Particle/Wave is an immersive multimedia exploration of gravitational waves where poetry, video art, music and science intersect. Following sell-out seasons at the Melbourne Festival 2018 and World Science Festival Brisbane come and see Particle/Wave under the planetarium dome.
Event.EventPayment: Price TBC

Event.EventName: STEM LIKE A PAT'S GIRL Conference 2019
Event.EventDescription: On Saturday 10 August, St Patrick's College Townsville will present the 3rd annual #STEM LIKE A PAT'S GIRL Conference 2019 - the only event of its kind in North Queensland. It is a day devoted to empowering and engaging girls aged 10 - 15 in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).

Meet the young scientists from Wodonga Middle Years College, St Anne’s Primary School in Albury and Galen Catholic College Wangaratta as they demonstrate their robotics and share their experiences from representing Australia at the 2019 VEX Robotics World Championships in Louisville, USA.

Event.EventName: Spectra: The Art and Consequence of Collaboration
Event.EventDescription: Spectra is a group exhibition featuring the work of Australian artists and designers working at the nexus of art and science. Illustrating the extraordinary potential for both disciplines, each work provokes new ways of experiencing and interpreting the world around us.
Get up close and personal with our creative technologies. Robotics, Virtual Reality headsets, 3D printing and more. A hands-on play session for adults.

Come along to see, learn and immerse the whole family in science this year at the Oliphant Science Awards Open Day. There will be a number of Science Spectacular Shows, Come & Try activities and all prize winning projects from the 2019 competition will be on display.
Event.EventPayment: Entry by gold coin donation

Event.EventDescription: Join us at GoodGrief Studios as we live paint a street art installation of the unique wonders of Tasmanian Science. There will be a meet and greet with the artist creating the work and the scientists that contributed, along with many art-meets-science activities.

Lego Challenge will ask participants to reproduce an image with Lego bricks. This is an introduction to scientific concepts through fun practical hands on experiences. Challenges are age appropriate. The activities will encourage both group and individual work.
Do you want to learn how to maximise the benefits of urban nature all around us? Come along to this introductory workshop and learn about the key benefits of Forest Therapy.

Back when science and art were better acquainted, we find a beautiful story weaving together the histories of women, art and science through cyanotype photography. Using a technique unchanged since the 1800s, join us to create your own blueprints of nature using the power of the Sun.

Get excited about SPACE at Campbelltown Library's SPACE Day! A FREE community event with scheduled talks, films, VR, crafts, food, prizes and more.
Saturday 10th August 9.30am-2pm Campbelltown Library 171 Montacute Rd Newton SA

The Circular Head Science Gig 2019 is a free family-friendly fun event with displays, hands-on experiments, activities and competitions for everyone. Come and check out the entries for our competitions and make a team to compete in the Macgyver Challenge. Lots to do and see!

Have you ever wondered what it's like to spend your life trying to unlock the secrets of an invisible world? Come and join us for an evening with a diverse group of microbiologists, hear all about their research/career and ask any burning questions you may have during our networking and Q & A event.

Event.EventName: Cosmos Calling - Space the Next Frontier
Event.EventDescription: A special Zonta Centenary event celebrates WA's Women in Space. A planetarium show 'Capturing the Cosmos' is followed by presentations and panel discussion, chaired by Prof Lyn Beazley, MC, to get inspired by the work and lives of Dr Natasha Hurley-Walker, Dr Katarina Miljkovic & Dr Ellie Sansom.
Event.EventPayment: Tickets $75 inclusive canapés, glass of wine and soft drinks, via Trybooking

Event.EventDescription: Learn how to make your own ice cream, play with slime.... Not only will you get to watch some wacky science, you'll get to try your hand at heaps of your own experiments! Plus you'll get to meet a selection of our friendly animals and learn all about the wildest branch of science - zoology!
Event.EventPayment: Only $3 per child, after normal Zoo admission.

Event.EventDescription: Discovery is ready to launch into National Science Week 2019 with Fly To The Moon. A fun filled night of hands-on science, space exploration and of course we have to kick it all off with a BANG!
Event.EventPayment: $12 for non members and $10 for members (children under 3 free)

Venue.VenueName: The Discovery Science and Technology Centre

Event.EventDescription: Spin yourself until you’re dizzy, compare your reflexes to a Formula 1 driver and see your fingertips under the microscope with the Shell Questacon Science Circus. The Marian Centre will be overflowing with exciting hands-on science exhibits and spectacular science shows.
Event.EventPayment: Adult $6, Students/Concession $5, Family $18, Children under 5 and Q Club Members FREE.

Venue.VenueName: The Marian Centre, OLSH Catholic College (Sadadeen Campus)

Event.EventDescription: Each year level has a task based on the ideas in the science teachers resource book “Destination Moon”. There will be rockets, lunar landers, eye spy space charts, space junk collectors, moon rovers, art works and poetry. This will be linked to watching the movie “ The Dish” at school.

The Innovators’ Tea Party are hosting eight free speed-networking events for students in Years 10, 11 and 12 to meet with a range of women working in a variety of science, technology, engineering, medicine and maths careers. Events are on Sunday 11 and Saturday 17 August at 9am, 11am, 1pm and 3pm.
Come and see the craters on the Moon, the cloud belts and moons of giant Jupiter, the beautiful rings of Saturn and the red sands of Mars through a variety of telescopes.

NEON is a site-specific, contemporary dance work by Hobart's youth dance company, DRILL. Start with a range of fun, scientific experiments with artistic outcomes, and then enter the free-roaming performance experience, where you are given the choice of how to watch and listen to the piece.
Event.EventPayment: $27 per ticket

Event.EventDescription: Have you seen an eagle up close? At this workshop, you'll meet our resident eagles, hawks, owls and more as you explore the Raptor Refuge and learn all about the rescue through to eventual release of injured raptors. Check out our huge flight aviaries, flight tunnel and our amazing education centre.
Event.EventPayment: $70 adults and $30 children

Event.EventDescription: Augment your reality. AI, bionics and smart devices are here to extend and enhance your senses. So what are the possible futures of human perception? At this event combining performance, storytelling, and experimentation, make sense of the world of the senses, and find the limits to your own. This event is recommended for an 16+ audience.
Event.EventPayment: General admission - $10 plus booking fee, Concession - $8 plus booking fee.
Event.EventMoreInfo: This event is recommended for an 16+ audience.

Event.EventName: Great Moments in Science with Dr Karl
Event.EventDescription: Dr Karl Kruszelnicki explains science as you've never heard it before. Celebrate the strange and wonderful place that is our universe with Australia's most popular science communicator. As Dr Karl explores some of the Great Moments in Science, he answers questions you never knew existed.
Event.EventPayment: Under 16s free; 16 and over $10

Event.EventDescription: Bots, Beers and Wine will be held at the historical Ben Ean winery in the Hunter Valley of NSW. The event aims to enhance the local communities understanding of how Science and Technology is having a positive impact on society in agriculture, advanced manufacturing, robotics and education.

Deakin University is hosting three Family Science Games Nights during National Science Week. Come along to an exciting evening playing scienceboard games. Have fun with family and friends and learn some science. Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.
Event.EventMoreInfo: Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.

Event.EventDescription: Deakin University is hosting three Family Science Games Nights during National Science Week. Come along to an exciting evening playing scienceboard games. Have fun with family and friends and learn some science. Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.
Event.EventMoreInfo: Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.

Event.EventName: United Science Passport: “Where in the world has science taken you?”
Event.EventDescription: Science is a human endeavour- crossing, national, cultural and continental divides. A dynamic display of the travels and stories that have brought scientists to the Waite campus.

Bioinformatics brings together the fields of life science, computer science and statistics, and Lachlan Gray will show you how when armed with nothing more than a laptop, internet connection and some basic coding skills, you can become a citizen scientist and conduct your own important research.

Deakin University is hosting three Family Science Games Night during National Science Week. Come along to an exciting evening playing scienceboard games. Have fun with family and friends and learn some science. Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.
Event.EventMoreInfo: Attendance is FREE but spaces are limited so please register through Eventbrite to secure your place.

Event.EventDescription: STEMtastic is a full day event with a number of STEM related organisations will be facilitating experiences to all Prep to Year 6 students and teachers and parents. A parent and community event including a guest speaker will be held at lunchtime.

Senior Lecturer at the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment, Paul Rymer, will fill us in on the research he has been conducting with Penrith City Council to find out which trees are the best for 'cooling the city'. Find out which tree species are able to survive and thrive in Western Sydney.

Event.EventName: To Infinity and Beyond Science Day
Event.EventDescription: "To Infinity and Beyond" Science day will showcase a range of hands-on science and technology experiments. Our day will incorporate the whole school reading "Counting on Katherine" and conduct rotations of classes presenting their science experiments and findings ending with a celebration assembly.

Our Junior Keeper Experience offers the unique opportunity for children aged 6 to 14 to get hands-on and experience behind the scenes action at Wing's Wildlife Park by engaging with wildlife and the keepers who manage them and assisting with food preparation and maintenance of wildlife enclosures.
Event.EventPayment: $65.00 per child (includes lunch). Payment required at time of booking.

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Lilydale
Event.EventDescription: Catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen with live Q&A. Download the app and explore the universe.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Building LB Boxhill Institute Lilydale Lakeside Campus 1 Jarlo Drive

Event.EventDescription: LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science.

LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science.

LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science.

LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science

LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science.

Event.EventName: Destination Moon in the WA Museum's Discovery Zone
Event.EventDescription: Destination Moon – More missions, more science, more fun – we’ve got it all covered in the Discovery Zone. From craters to comets, you’ll be over the moon after participating in this week’s activities!

Venue.VenueStreetName: State Library of WA Perth Cultural Centre

Event.EventDescription: Come along to a very special SciPub event! SciPub is teaming up with local director Rowan Harris and a fantastic team of local improvisation artists for an evening blending SciPub style science communication with improvisation theatre. It promises to be buckets of fun!

A week-long program of events for students that will incorporate the Destination Moon theme and highlight the Year of the Periodic Table. Activities will include building a solar powered Moon rover and a moonscape to test it on, moonscape walk with VR goggles, Astronomy Club night and space food.

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Wangaratta
Event.EventDescription: Catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen with live Q&A. Download the app and explore the universe.

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Romsey
Event.EventDescription: Catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen with live Q&A. Download the app and explore the universe.

Event.EventName: This Sounds Like Science: Why Music is Maths
Event.EventDescription: Join Professor Geordie Williamson for a journey into the shape of sound and sound waves to explore the fascinating world of timbre, overtones, modes and frequencies. These ideas are amongst the most fundamental tools of modern mathematics and physics.

Event.EventName: Codebugs and Strawbees: Building digital structures
Event.EventDescription: Our 'STEM Girls' club will investigate mathematical, physics and engineering concepts by building 'Strawbees' structures and connecting these creations to a digital coding solution using Codebugs. These projects will be presented to the school community during National Science Week and our Book Fair evening.

Event.EventName: Shells- How Beach Ecosystems Respond to the Environment by Matt Kerr
Event.EventDescription: Ever picked up a seashell and wondered why it looked like it did, or why the shell from another holiday looks so different? Meet Macquarie University PhD candidate Matt Kerr who is researching variation in beach shells across Australia to learn how beach ecosystems respond to the environment.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Lower Ground, The Concourse 409 Victoria Avenue

Event.EventName: The Other Side of Cannabis with Michael Udoh
Event.EventDescription: What is Cannabis? Big claims vs scientific fact. Recent discoveries... Future outlook. Increasingly, cannabis is viewed as much more than a recreational drug. Join Michael Udoh, a molecular pharmacology PhD candidate at Macquarie University, to discover another side of cannabis.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Lower Ground, The Concourse 409 Victoria Avenue

Event.EventName: Stars and Science at Speers Point Park - Lake Mac STEAM Family Day
Event.EventDescription: Paint a starry night, take A Trip to the Moon, search the stars and become a scientist at Lake Mac STEAM Week’s highlight event. Food truck and dinner options will be available for purchase.
Event.EventPayment: Gold coin donation

Event.EventName: Alanta Colley: Parasites Lost - The story of one woman, who has contained multitudes.
Event.EventDescription: Parasites Lost combines science communication, storytelling, and comedy in a parable on parasites. It is a unique opportunity to learn about the secret life of some of the most ingenious micro-organisms, from someone who’s played host to a bunch of them.
Event.EventPayment: Tickets $15 per person

Event.EventName: Alanta Colley: Parasites Lost - The story of one woman, who has contained multitudes.
Event.EventDescription: Parasites Lost combines science communication, storytelling, and comedy in a parable on parasites. It is a unique opportunity to learn about the secret life of some of the most ingenious micro-organisms, from someone who’s played host to a bunch of them.
Event.EventPayment: Tickets $15 per person

Event.EventName: Urban Ecology with Dr Manuel Esperon-Rodriguez
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Manuel Esperon-Rodriguez from the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment at Western Sydney University, for a freewheeling discussion on urban ecology. Discover how the successes and failures of urban plantings are used to improve urban planning and secure ecosystems in a changing climate.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Lower Ground, The Concourse 409 Victoria Avenue

Event.EventDescription: LAUNCH TO THE FUTURE is a science sketch comedy presentation focusing on how space programs and lunar science propel us into the future using STEM! In a series of comical skits, professional actor/educators use audience suggestions to create uniquely hilarious scenes educating us about space science.

Join the Newcastle Astronomical Association for an informative and fun night of stargazing. Navigate your way to Jupiter and Saturn with the virtual spacecraft before experiencing the thrill of seeing them with your own eyes through the telescope. This is an event for people of all ages.

After 'Together Tuesday Lunch, Lunar Lunch' on Tuesday 13 August our entire school will plant seedlings and seeds in all of the vegetable gardens within the school grounds. We will monitor the growth and make food to share when harvested.
National Science Week 2019 is all about Destination Moon. Come and explore, play, inquire and be challenged by the complexities and problems of lunar exploration.

Event.EventName: Glancing with the Stars: An evening of sky watching, astronomy and physics.
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Brad Tucker and his team for an evening learning about the latest research, technological advances and Australia's contribution to space exploration. After the speech, venture outside to look up to the skies and enjoy the spectacle of cosmic objects up close through a telescope.

Venue.VenueName: Trinity Bay State High School Theatre

Event.EventName: Darwin Mission Moon Science Week EveNT
Event.EventDescription: The Mission Moon EveNT is an expo for students, aged 6-9, in the Darwin/Palmerston region, to share the Moon base the Show Me poster they have completed during First Lego League Junior. Students will share their work with each other and a wider audience, including other schools and the community.

Venue.VenueName: Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory

Event.EventDescription: The Mission Moon EveNT is an expo for students, aged 6-9, in the Alice Springs region, to share the Moon base the Show Me poster they have completed during First Lego League Junior. Students will share their work with each other and a wider audience, including other schools and the community.
At San Sisto College we will celebrate National Science Week by building Lego models of the Apollo Saturn V Rocket and building and launching model rockets.

Event.EventName: STEM Together and Star Gazing Evening
Event.EventDescription: A family night encouraging participation in STEM, space and science. Have a go at hands-on STEM tasks, explore the night's sky, problem solve and get thinking about science. A great chance to share science together.

Event.EventName: The Future of Quantum Computing: Paul Webster
Event.EventDescription: Join Paul Webster, a quantum computing researcher from The University of Sydney, and break through the hype and mystery to learn what quantum computers are, why we don't have them yet, and what it could mean for medicine, food and more once we do.

BeakerStreet@TMAG is a pop-up science bar, a parlour of curiosities, an inn for inquiring minds. You will encounter entrancing live music, zoological oddities, amiable wandering scientists, seriously good food and drink, and such a bounty of distractions, you may forget to go home.

Celebrate National Science Week with your children at a community event at the Brolga Theatre on Tuesday evening 13 August. A panel of young STEM professionals will speak about the amazing work they do and what a career in STEM is all about. There will also be interactive STEM displays.
Event.EventContactOrganisation: Office of the Qld Chief Scientist

Event.EventName: Narara Valley High School STEM Day
Event.EventDescription: Students in Yr 7 will design and build a parachute that will land on Mars and Yr 8 students will build rockets that they will launch.
During National Science Week we aim to reach out to as many students around the college, to promote science awareness, through participation of hands-on and interactive activities.

Event.EventName: Are smart phones making us dumb? Professor Mark Williams
Event.EventDescription: Professor Mark Williams explores the idea: Are smart phones making us dumb? Mark is a Professor of Cognitive Neuroscience at Macquarie University. Discover how our use of digital devices may be affecting our brains and therefore the reality we 'see'.

Event.EventName: Green building for the sea: Kate Dodds
Event.EventDescription: Part of Sydney Science Festival, learn about the innovative Living Seawalls project that is returning marine life to urban shorelines with Macquarie University Marine Ecologist and PhD researcher Kate Dodds.

This is an AMOS event to enable people to ask/submit any questions and concerns to a panel of experts in their fields. People are encouraged to submit any questions beforehand. The panel will be headed by Dr Kate Auty, ACT Commissioner for Sustainability and the Environment

Venue.VenueStreetName: Building 188, Fellows Lane Australian National University

Event.EventDescription: Using high voltage spark discharges, Sean O'Connell reveals the individual qualities and internal structures of matter in this exhibition.

Event.EventName: The Al – Zr of the Periodic Table
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Alice Motion, Dr Karl Kruszelnicki and Adam Spencer for an entertaining night of science where you’ll get up close with the chemical elements to celebrate the International Year of the Periodic Table this National Science Week.
Event.EventContactName: Partner Engagment & Outreach Faculty of Science

Venue.VenueName: The University of Sydney - Great Hall

Event.EventDescription: Wait Wait...Save Our Species! is a live comedy event where we will dissect and discuss prominent and obscure biodiversity and conservation news. Have the chance to participate filling in the final limerick words/phrase and telling truth from fiction. Come laugh, learn, and help save our species.

Students of Moil Primary School will be participating in interactive activities and holding a stall showcasing some of the best science work and experiments they have done in class. Parents, community, and neighboring schools will be invited.
Event.EventPayment: Gold coin donation or cost of buying work.

Event.EventDescription: A field day on Country in the Midlands Biodiversity Hot Spot with scientists, historian Bill Gammage, farmers, Aboriginal educators and students, exploring the issues around land management and restoration.
Event.EventPayment: A bus will take participants from Hobart. The event is free for members of Greening Australia. (Membership - $60). Non-members $70.00. Lunch and morning tea included.

Event.EventDescription: A thought-provoking event focussed on Aboriginal land management in Australia and the implications this has for addressing current restoration practices.
Event.EventPayment: General $30.00; Concession: $20.00; Aboriginal Community and Greening Australia members: Free

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Bendigo
Event.EventDescription: Catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen with live Q&A. Download the app and explore the universe.

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Mountain Goat Brewery
Event.EventDescription: Grab a delicious craft beer and catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen. Download the app and explore the universe. Mini VR headsets provided on arrival.

The Huon STEM Expo will involve 10 Huon Valley Schools coming together with the community to celebrate and explore innovations in STEM. This will include technology, renewable energy and activities re-using waste materials.

Event.EventName: Airds Community of Schools Science Spectacular
Event.EventDescription: Students from our feeder primary schools and our Year 7 and 8 students will be involved in hands-on learning rotating through different workshops coordinated by teachers and stage 5 students, designed to increase awareness of our current STEM and coding programs the school has to offer.

The Science Trivia Challenge follows conventional trivia nights with six rounds of eight questions. In between rounds there will be entertainment by way of “whiz-bang-pop” hands-on, science demonstrations and brain-buster questions for the audience!
Event.EventPayment: Cost of $25 per team (invoiced post event)

Event.EventDescription: The Mountain Heights School Science Fair will showcase the projects undertaken by Year 6-10 students for the UTAS Science and Engineering Investigation Awards and Primary Space Science projects.

Dedicated programming for primary school students on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 6 to 15 August. The 2019 Science Festival offers to bring practical science to life with a specially designed primary school program packed with hands-on activities and explosive workshops.
Event.EventPayment: $5 Expo entry plus additional for more activities

Event.EventDescription: Take part in pedalling our stationary bikes to make the equivalent amount of energy required to screen positive films about the technological and community adjustments we can make for a sustainable future. You can power your popcorn and smoothies too, while you watch these inspiring films!
Event.EventPayment: $5 per person

Event.EventDescription: Take a trip through time to the ancient land of Gondwana for a fantastic family day of hands-on science fun at the Blue Mountains Botanic Garden.

Venue.VenueName: Blue Mountains Botanic Garden Mount Tomah

Event.EventDescription: Join us for a night of astronomy, star gazing and storytelling surrounded by the new carnivorous plant display at The Calyx, a beautiful building in the heart of the Royal Botanic Garden Sydney.
Event.EventPayment: Adult tickets: $39; Member adults: $35; Bookings: Essential Online. **Likely to sell out - book early to avoid disappointment**

Venue.VenueStreetName: Royal Botanic Garden Sydney Mrs Macquaries Road

Event.EventDescription: Experience the Garden and its fascinating night-life on this adventure by torch-light for families. Wander the garden pathways and visit biodiversity 'hotspots' such as the ponds to look for nocturnal animals - we may see Golden Orb spiders, Brush-tailed Possums, Microbats, and more.
Event.EventPayment: Who: Families with children 5 and older. Cost: Members $35 | Non-members $39. Tickets sold per person. Bookings: Essential online.

Event.EventDescription: Children will separate into groups with a teacher and parents and rotate through a variety of science based activities.
Join PlantBank scientists in their labs and find out about their fascinating work.
Event.EventPayment: $25 (wine and snacks included)

Venue.VenueName: The Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan, PlantBank

Event.EventDescription: We will show you the stars over the Garden…

Venue.VenueName: The Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan, Lakeside Lawn

Event.EventName: Painting with Light - Photography with Peter Solness
Event.EventDescription: Paint with light and learn how to take breathtaking unique time exposure photos!
Where music and science meet - enjoy Holst's "Planets" and a night of stargazing.
Event.EventPayment: $35 per ticket; $100 family ticket

Venue.VenueStreetName: crn Loch Avenue South and Dicken's Drive

Event.EventDescription: Join our experienced Rangers for a fascinating and surprising spotlight walk to see how the Park transforms when the Sun goes down.
Event.EventPayment: $20 per person

Event.EventName: Science in the Swamp - Dinosaurs vs Superpowers
Event.EventDescription: Dinosaurs and Superpowers in Centennial Park. Batman, Spiderman, Wonder Woman, or Catwoman - we all know about their fantastic strength and abilities. Come and find out about nature and science's amazing superpower at this family fun day out. Don't forget to dress up!

Venue.VenueStreetName: crn Dickens Drive and Loch Avenue South

Event.EventName: Science in the Wild - Dinosaurs vs Superpowers
Event.EventDescription: Dinosaurs and Superpowers in The Australian Botanic Garden. Batman, Spiderman, Wonder Woman, or Cat woman - we all know about their fantastic strength and abilities - come out and see what superpowers science and nature have. Don't forget to dress up!

Venue.VenueName: The Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan, Lakeside Lawn

Event.EventName: Festival of Bright Ideas Schools Day
Event.EventDescription: The 2019 Festival of Bright Ideas is exploding with science for all your senses. See, hear and feel what’s happening in science in Tasmania through innovation, research and technology – plus you’ll discover science alive in some of the most unexpected places!

Event.EventName: Shine Bright Little Science Explorers Program
Event.EventDescription: During National Science Week we will run our "Shine Bright Little Scientist" program. Using a play-based pedagogy, children can be given the opportunity to investigate, manipulate and experiment with a wide range of resources and materials that develop concepts, skills and dispositions.
A three or four day workshop on model rocket design, construction, launch and recovery. This will begin with simple bottle rockets and progress to small engine driven recoverable model rockets.

Sizzling Solar Ovens is a five day project where senior students and parents will transform the Special Ed Unit into a solar ovens lab. Using recycled materials teams will connect STEM with sustainability on multiple levels.

Event.EventName: Southern Cross Early Childhood School Big Bird Box Project
Event.EventDescription: This STEM project will provide students with an insight into the practical application of STEM in the real world and highlight how STEM can benefit the local community. It will provide an opportunity to engage with the broader community and strengthen our connections with them.

Event.EventName: The Ambidextrous Brain: The Neuroscience of Imagination & Creativity.
Event.EventDescription: Getting the most out of your brain’s extraordinary powers requires understanding its cognitive cycle. Usually trained to be focused and narrow, the brain can be divergent and creative if given the chance.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Level 6, Sydney Startup Hub 11 - 17 York Street

Event.EventDescription: Creating a frog-friendly garden: Open garden; Practical demonstrations; Frog facts; How to use the FrogID app; Live frog and tadpole displays.

By 2050 there will be more plastic in the sea than fish. Our FREE community screening of BLUE takes us on a provocative journey into the ocean realm. We meet those who are defending habitats, campaigning for smarter fishing, combating marine pollution and fighting for the protection of species.

Students make tissue papaer hot air balloons and then fill them using portable bunsen burners and release them. They gain an understanding of physics concepts including density, displacement and unbalanced forces.

Students and parents/carers are invited to an evening at the school to celebrate science with students and staff. Together they will be encouraged to build "Scribble-Bots", view science displays, share a meal and engage with staff attending.

This Year 7-10 Science Fair day will showcase student work and celebrate the amazing world of science. Poster displays will be staffed by students, so come and have a chat and see what interests our future science leaders.

Venue.VenueName: Performing Arts Centre, Baldivis Secondary College

Event.EventName: Meet Citizen Scientists at Parramatta Library
Event.EventDescription: A panel of scientists will provide information how everyone can get involved with local projects and research. It provides opportunity for Q&A. It is an event for everyone.
Event.EventPayment: $3.00 per ticket

Event.EventDescription: A joint interactive event with Western Sydney University, Parramatta Library will see participants interacting with Pepper and Nao, the humanoid robots. Dr Omar Mubin will demonstrate how robots work and what they can do in our life. The event opens to participants aged 8 and over. Book online.
Event.EventPayment: $3.00 per person

Event.EventDescription: We will be hosting a journey through the Andamooka night skies using naked eye astronomy and telescopes to observe the Earth's Moon, constellations, Jupiter and Saturn.

Event.EventName: Discover how pre-schoolers and their educators are changing human-computer design processes.
Event.EventDescription: Dr Holly Tootell is passionate about technology advocacy and public dialogue, particularly the sensitive topic of technology and early childhood. Discover how pre-schoolers and their educators are changing human-computer design processes.

Our planet has seen some massive climatic changes over the last one hundred million years, but more recent changes tell us that we’re in for a bumpy ride. Ever wondered how climate scientists gaze into the future by looking at the past?

Venue.VenueStreetName: Cnr Queens Road and Dora Street

Event.EventName: What a Worm Can Teach Us About Our Brains
Event.EventDescription: Learn how scientists discover information about humans by studying other life forms. Dr Yee Lian Chew explains how her research at the University of Wollongong uses the brain of a tiny worm, C. elegans to reveal new information about the human brain.
Find out about nanotechnology and cancer from Dr Wei Deng from UNSW. This event is part of Inspiring Australia’s Talking Science series as part of Sydney Science Festival in National Science Week.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Cnr Flushcombe Road and Alpha Street

Event.EventDescription: The Inspire Science Expo invites teachers, students, parents and all community members to join the festivities that celebrate all things STEM at the Narangba State School Fete. See into the world of STEM through interactive activities and insightful demonstrations.

Event.EventName: What’s innovative about neurology? “Time is Brain” and its importance to stroke
Event.EventDescription: What happens when there is a bleeding in the brain or a brain artery is blocked? Join in a Live conversation with Dr Sonu Bhaskar on strokes, latest breakthroughs in acute treatments, and the importance of rapid access to time-critical therapies. Stay for an origami making craft session afterward.

Event.EventName: What’s innovative about neurology? Building dementia friendly communities
Event.EventDescription: Join in a Live conversation with Dr Sonu Bhaskar about dementia, it's impacts, and how can we build dementia friendly communities. After the talk, stay for an origami making craft session. The art of paper folding can help develop coordination and memory.

Discover how you can help scientists collect data about our environment. Presented by biologist Dr. Koa Webster. Scoop a Poop collection kits will be available at the end of the session. This event is part of Inspiring Australia’s Talking Science series as part of Sydney Science Festival.

Event.EventName: ARTSCI – Where Art impacts with Science
Event.EventDescription: Come and enjoy the ARTSCI exhibition final at CSIRO/NMI on Saturday 17 August. An afternoon of fun for all the family with Fizzics science show & live viewing of artworks and science installations! Competition finals winners announced. Chief Scientist for CSIRO, Dr Cathy Foley judging.
An afternoon workshop inviting sparky thinkers and their parents/guardians to dive deep and engineer a whole lot of awesomeness using introductory electronics.
Event.EventPayment: Each MiniSparx + BigSparx (child plus adult) ticket costs $20. Any additional adult or child tickets on top of family entry are $10 each.

Event.EventDescription: Super Science Saturday is about showcasing the science behind one of Sydney's most loved institutions, the Australian Museum. With live animals,hands-on experiments and outrageous science demonstrations, there are activities that will appeal to the littlies, teenagers and the parents.
Event.EventPayment: $10 for general public, free for a limited number of Australian Museum members.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Cnr College Street and Liverpool Street

Event.EventDescription: Dr Katie Sizeland will discuss how she is uncovering the nanostructure of nature's superhero fibre collagen.Dr Stacey Priestley will address what groundwater is, where it is and how it is studied. And Dr Jo Lackenby will talk about the mysterious blue glow- how nuclear reactors work.

Event.EventName: Immersive Science III (SciVR): Astronomy for all Australians - Gold Coast
Event.EventDescription: Catch the latest news in black holes with Alan Duffy and Rebecca Allen with live Q&A. Download the app and explore the universe.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Cnr Lindfield Road and Sir John Overall Drive

Event.EventName: Science Talks at Warringah Mall Library
Event.EventDescription: Celebrate Sydney Science Festival & National Science Week at the Library with talks by Prof. Annabelle McIver, Rokiah Alford and David Bishop.
Join us in celebrating Sydney Science Festival & National Science Week with talks by Giulia Filippini, Raffaela Abbriano & Audrey Commault.

Event.EventName: PsychTalks Stories From the Cosmos: What Indigenous storytelling can teach us about memory, our highways and ourselves
Event.EventDescription: For over 65 000 years, the night sky has served as a map for Indigenous peoples all around the world. Cultures have long grouped stars into familiar patterns and many of these constellations are perceived in strikingly similar ways, despite the cultures being geographically separated.

Join microbiologist Dr Laura McCaughey from the University of Technology Sydney and the University of Oxford, UK, for a fascinating look at the role vaccines play in helping to slow the spread of antibiotic resistant bacteria.

Venue.VenueStreetName: State Library of NSW Macquarie Street

Event.EventDescription: What is hoarding disorder, why does it develop and how can it be treated? Join Associate Professor Melissa Norberg, the Deputy Director for the Centre of Emotional Health at Macquarie University, to learn why we can be motivated to acquire possessions we do not need.

Venue.VenueStreetName: State Library of NSW Macquarie Street

Event.EventDescription: Little Explorers Big Day Out is about showcasing the science behind one of Sydney's most loved festivals, the Australian Museums Science in the City. All workshops, shows and activities are set to entertain and engage curious little minds.
Event.EventPayment: $10 general entry

Event.EventName: Coding a virtual spacecraft in HappyBrackets - Sydney
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Angelo Fraietta as he explores how to make studying astronomy both creative and fun. Learn how to program the virtual spacecraft and travel to various places using Stellarium planetarium software in this creative coding workshop.

Event.EventName: Coding a virtual spacecraft in HappyBrackets - Sydney
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Angelo Fraietta as he explores how to make studying astronomy both creative and fun. Learn how to program the virtual spacecraft and travel to various places using Stellarium planetarium software in this creative coding workshop.

Event.EventName: Coding a virtual spacecraft in HappyBrackets
Event.EventDescription: Join Dr Angelo Fraietta as he explores how to make studying astronomy both creative and fun. Learn how to program the virtual spacecraft and travel to various places using Stellarium planetarium software in this creative coding workshop.

Event.EventName: Order and Progress: A Sonic Segue Across A Auriverde
Event.EventDescription: Archaeoastronomical techniques are used with the Stellarium planetarium software to simulate the astronomy over Rio de Janeiro at the moment the Republic of Brazil was declared. This work is an example of how scientific data can be used to blend political symbology, scientific data and music.

Science fiction writer David M Henley and science journalist Alice Klein sit down together to discuss fakery, truth and objectivity in the world of science and the latest trends in social media technology

Event.EventName: Moon Mysteries - a celebration of our nearest celestial neighbour with Prof Fred Watson
Event.EventDescription: Celebrate National Science Week 2019 with a public lecture by Australia's first Astronomer-at-large.

Event.EventName: Marvel at the Moon and Stars with MAGNT
Event.EventDescription: Embark on a 3D outer space experience in Starlab’s Cosmodome Science Theatre & Planetarium at the Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory. Brilliant 3D depictions of our solar system, moon phases, eclipses and tidal rhythms combined with surround-sound effects will captivate you.
Event.EventPayment: Event ticket $5. Children under 15 must be accompanied by an adult. MAGNT has free general admission.

Event.EventDescription: The largest astronomy festival in the country is beaming in from NASA for the anniversary of the Moon Landing. The team from Houston will be talking with us live as we catch up about this years celebrations.
Event.EventPayment: $10 Adults; $5 Concession/Pension/Student/Uni. 12 years and under free. Planetarium, virtual reality and kids workshops are additional costs.

Event.EventDescription: The largest astronomy festival in the country is beaming in from NASA for the anniversary of the Moon Landing. The team from Houston will be talking with us live as we catch up about this years celebrations.
Event.EventPayment: $10 Adults; $5 Concession/Pension/Student/Uni. 12 years and under free. Planetarium, virtual reality and kids workshops are additional costs.

Event.EventDescription: Be a Junior Paleontologist and dig a real fossil out of a matrix and take it home for your own collection and it's totally free. Get to hold and see lots of real fossils from Dino Poo through to a full Mammoth tooth. Lots of interesting things to look at. Open 9 - 5 Mon to Fri and 11 - 5 Sat & Sun.

Be a Junior Geologist. Dig real semi-precious gemstones out of a matrix and after identifying them take them home for your own collection for free. Look at all of the wonderful rocks and minerals we have that you can hold and investigate while at the event.

Event.EventName: Women in STEM Conference at Melbourne Zoo (all schools)
Event.EventDescription: Females are drastically underrepresented in STEM subjects and jobs across the planet – let’s change that! On the eve of National Science Week 2019, educate and inspire your Year 7–10 students by connecting with real-world STEM mentors and case studies. This conference is especially for secondary schools.
Event.EventPayment: $19 per student (normal Zoo entry). Free for any accompanying teachers and adults.

Event.EventName: Women in STEM Conference at Melbourne Zoo (Catholic Schools)
Event.EventDescription: Females are drastically underrepresented in STEM subjects and jobs across the planet – let’s change that! On the eve of National Science Week 2019, educate and inspire your Year 7–10 students by connecting with real-world STEM mentors and case studies. This conference is especially for Catholic Schools.
Event.EventPayment: $19 per student (normal Zoo entry). Free for any accompanying teachers and adults.

Event.EventDescription: Become a scientist for the day at our huge outdoor science celebration! Explore the Garden like you’ve never done before: get hands-on with science experiments, explore behind-the-scenes, visit state-of-the-art science facilities and use scientific equipment. There's fun for everyone!

Venue.VenueStreetName: Mrs Macquaries Road Lawns inside Woolloomooloo Gate

Event.EventDescription: Science Alive! is the largest single interactive science exhibition in Australia, and brings together the South Australia’s big names in science and technology. We’ll have over 60 exhibitors providing hands-on fun that is interactive, dynamic, fun, and educational for all ages!
Event.EventPayment: At the door: Adults: $20; Concession: $15. Online*: Adults: $18; Concession: $14 *plus booking fee. FREE for all those under 18 years of age. On sale from June 3!

Event.EventName: STEM Skill Logic Games - Come and Try
Event.EventDescription: Try your hand at some of the best STEM skill teaching games around. Select from our large range of Thinkfun games and spend some time challenging yourself in logic, spatial awareness and programming sequencing logic. There are games for all types of thinking in many skill development areas.
Join us to celebrate National Science Week and our latest exhibition, Pets are People Too, with this fascinating panel discussion on the psychology of pets.

Venue.VenueStreetName: Brighton Town Hall Cnr Carpenter and Wilson Streets

Event.EventDescription: Smoke cannons, liquid nitrogen, flame tests, explosions, and cool chemistry experiments are headed for Brisbane central. Brisbane Science Festival will bring science to life using a range of interactive activities, guest presentations, and captivating science demonstrations.
Event.EventPayment: Tickets to be released in June.

Event.EventName: Indigenous Science Experience - Primary School Sessions
Event.EventDescription: This annual event for primary school students is a celebration of Indigenous and Western science and highlights the relevance of science, technology, engineering and mathematics to our everyday lives. It includes a wide range of hands-on, interactive science activities.

Event.EventName: Indigenous Science Experience - Family Fun Day
Event.EventDescription: This annual, free, community open event is a celebration of Indigenous and Western science and highlights the relevance of science, technology, engineering and mathematics to our everyday lives. This event will include a wide range of hands-on, interactive science activities accessible to all ages.

Event.EventName: Kingswood High School Science Week Open Night
Event.EventDescription: The Kingswood High School Science Week Open Night is an annual event showcasing work surrounding the theme of Science week. We have a number of presentations and displays from various organisations as well as opening up our themed classrooms for interative fun and engagement for the community.
Event.EventPayment: $4 entry fee which includes a sausage sandwich and can of drink.

Event.EventDescription: James Cook University, Tanks Art Centre and PechaKucha Cairns are hosting National Science Week PechaKucha at The Tanks Arts Centre on 14 August (7:30pm start). Come and hear exciting science stories, and talk to scientists tackling big problems. $5 cover-charge, with gold coin donation.
Event.EventPayment: $5 cover-charge applies, plus $1 gold coin donation.

Event.EventName: Destination Moon for Primary School Students
Event.EventDescription: Students will make and fire rockets to "the moon" and make models of the Earth and its moon to explore the orbit and phases of the Moon and the role the Moon plays in the ocean's tides.

Event.EventName: Destination Moon for Primary School Students
Event.EventDescription: Students will make and fire rockets to "the moon" and make models of the Earth and its moon to explore the orbit and phases of the Moon and the role the Moon plays in the ocean's tides.

Event.EventName: Destination Moon for Primary School Students
Event.EventDescription: Students will make and fire rockets to "the moon" and make models of the Earth and its moon to explore the orbit and phases of the Moon and the role the Moon plays in the ocean's tides.

Kain, Nick and Stig from Booderee National Park will speak of the Bush Tucker section in the Botanic Garden, the progress of the quolls and other introduced species and the propagation of Jervis Bay's very own, and very rare, Banksia Vincentia.

Kain, Nick and Stig from Booderee National Park will speak of the Bush Tucker section of the Botanic Gardens, the progress of the quolls and others intriduced sepcies and the propagation of our very own, and very rare, Banksia Vincentia.
Dr Nathan Knott (DPI) will host six local marine scientists who will present their cutting-edge research.
Dr Nathan Knott (DPI) will host six local marine scientists who will present their cutting-edge research.

Event.EventName: Introduction to Botanical Drawing and Painting
Event.EventDescription: This Introduction to Botanical Drawing and Painting Weekend Workshop will be conducted by local nature artist, Peter Wale, in the grounds of the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum. Suitable for beginners and those with some experience. Contact the Museum for a list of equipment required.
Event.EventPayment: $150 for the weekend workshop

Event.EventDescription: A travelling exhibition from the Sydney Observatory, Winning Sky is a collection of astrophotographs from the David Malin Awards.
Event.EventPayment: Cost of entry to the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum

Event.EventDescription: Draw National Science Week to a close at Jervis Bay Maritime Museum: rug up and come along for a sausage sizzle and drinks. There will be music, information about sharks, bees and the birds and flora of the Museum grounds . Enjoy short science films and Moon gazing with the Shoalhaven Astronomers.

Celebrate the 50th anniversary of the first lunar landing at the Huskisson Pictures. There will be drinks and nibbles before Dr John Harris gives a summary of the 50th anniversary celebrations at Parkes Observatory then sit back and enjoy the iconic Australian film, The Dish.
A photographic competition with Our Moon as the inspiration. Come to see photographers' artistic interpretation of the topic, a homage to our moon and to the 50th anniversary of the lunar landing.
Event.EventPayment: Entry fee to the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum

Event.EventDescription: Local Jervis Bay science lovers will share their passion: Voyager II; Between Sound and Silence: how technology is combating hearing loss; What happens to the human body in space; Jervis Bay Marine Rescue's radio room and vessels; Fitzroy, his barometer and weather forecasting.

Noela Lim from local bookshop, Boobook on Owen, will lead this discussion of science books: fiction and non-fiction. Join in the discussion of your favourite science books and share your collective interest in all types and branches of science.

Event.EventName: Fair is foul and foul is fair
Event.EventDescription: Whether the weather is foul or fair come to the Jervis Bay Maritime Museum to explore the twists and turns of meteorology with a RAN meteorologist and oceanographer. Learn about cloud formations, the weather map and the science behind weather forecasting.
Learn about the science of Naval Gunnery with LCDR David Jones RAN. Explore the engineering, maths and physics of the HMAS Sydney - Emden battle of 1914. Be prepared to get active and go ballistic.

Come to Tec-NQ's Open Day to learn all about the application of STEM skills in the trades.Get hands-on with trade technology in electrotechnology, automotive, engineering and more! Talk to the trade trainers and students to learn more about your future career in the trades.

Come to the opening of Jervis Bay Maritime Museum's two photographic exhibitions: "Winning Sky": the David Malin Awards for astro-photography; and "Our Moon": a photographic competition open to the general public and to school students.

Science Gallery Melbourne's pop-up program DISPOSABLE will highlight experimental and creative ways to tackle our ever growing excess of waste. DISPOSABLE locations will include The University of Melbourne's Parkville and Southbank campuses, along with unique sites throughout Melbourne.
Geelong Gallery presents a major exhibition titled The Moon to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the first Moon landing.

Soapbox Science Sydney is a free, interactive, public event showcasing female researchers in Science, Technology, Engineering, Maths and Medicine. Picture an iconic backdrop and 12 enthusiastic researchers on soapboxes discussing their research with anyone and everyone who happens to walk past.

The presentation about the Adelaide Dolphin Sanctuary by Dr Mike Bossley is offered free to the general public. In addition the South Australian Maritime Museum will offer special dolphin search cruises in National Science Week 2019.

A laboratory style experimental setup of a steam distillation unit showcasing the live process of eucalyptus oil extraction. The audience can engage through their senses of sight, smell and touch and get actively involved in the discussion.
Discover some of the disastrous consequences of climate change, pollution and intensive agriculture on nature’s ecosystem as Dr Sanchez– Bayo discusses the global decline of insect populations.

The Science in the Park event at the Coolart Wetlands and Homestead Reserve in Somers, will be the focus of free science activities on the Mornington Peninsula catering for all ages.
Meet NASA Scientist Dr Darlene Lim to learn about life in extreme Earth habitats and beyond!

In celebration of National Science Week, the Urrbrae Wetland is hosting a special Open Day inviting families, individuals and small groups to come and learn about the ecology and functioning of this man-made wetland.

Students studying STEM or STEAM subjects are invited to meet Kings Park’s female science and conservation staff in Kings Park to gain an insight into the rewarding career opportunities in the areas of ecology, seed science, genetics and plant conservation.
Event.EventPayment: $175.00 - $300.00 per class (depending on class size)

Event.EventDescription: Urrbrae High School is hosting a series of interactive science workshops, inviting primary groups to attend and experience the wonderful aspects of Science at Urrbrae including the Wetland (sustainability and nature), Farm (paddock to plate) and Science Labs (experiments).
Event.EventPayment: Free

Event.EventDescription: INDIGI HACK is a two-day hackathon targeted at Indigenous youth aged 8-18. Through INDIGI HACK youth compete to develop new app-based technology that aims to revitalise and retain Indigenous languages.

'Molecule' is a visual art exhibition showcasing a series of artworks by Tutti Artist Charlie Taplin. His latest works are an exploration of microscopic inspired imagery and have a particular focus on medical themes.

Venue.VenueName: Royal Adelaide Hospital - Emerging Artist Galleries

Event.EventDescription: Dr Peter Skilton of the Mornington Peninsula Astronomical Society will talk about the Moon landings and astronomy.

Event.EventName: Destination Moon & Beyond with Ben Z
Event.EventDescription: Join Ben Z of Fizzics Education as he takes you to Destination Moon and Beyond.

YMCA Canberra Space Squad is Australia's only live-in camp program for students in Years 6-9 who love space! It is a five day action-packed school holiday space experience that you won’t want to miss.
Event.EventPayment: Pricing to be confirmed

Event.EventDescription: YMCA Canberra Space Squad is Australia's only live-in camp program for students in Years 6-9 who love space! It is a five day action-packed school holiday space experience that you won’t want to miss.
Event.EventPayment: Pricing to be confirmed.
